title: 111_hr3703
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". The Congress acknowledges that Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are rapidly increasing in the U.S., affecting all demographics. The rate of autism has risen from 1 in 10,000 in the 1980s to 1 in 150 currently, indicating an epidemic. New cases of autism are diagnosed approximately every 20 minutes, with no signs of slowing down. Autism is diagnosed every 20 minutes, with more children being diagnosed with autism than with AIDS, diabetes, and cancer combined. The cost of autism to the nation is over $35 billion per year, expected to increase in the next decade. The educational, labor, housing, and medical communities are ill-equipped to handle individuals with autism, potentially depriving the nation of a future workforce. Autism spectrum disorders are a significant societal concern, with autism research receiving less funding compared to other childhood diseases. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated nearly $1 billion for autism research. The Combating Autism Act allocated almost $1 billion for autism research, focusing on environmental factors, treatments, early identification, and support services. A White House Conference on Autism aims to advance scientific study and analysis of cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF THE CONFERENCE. The President is required to call the White House Conference on Autism by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations on combating autism in the US. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing and Urban Development will plan and conduct the Conference. The White House Conference on Autism, to be convened by the President in consultation with the Surgeon General, aims to galvanize a national effort to find the causes of autism, identify solutions for individuals and families, develop a research agenda, and bring together parents and scientific experts. The White House Conference on Autism, convened by the President in consultation with the Surgeon General, aims to bring together parents of autistic children and leaders in education and social services to address lifelong challenges. It also seeks to highlight innovative programs for autistic individuals and review the effectiveness of existing legislation and programs at the Federal, State, and local levels. The White House Conference on Autism aims to review existing legislation and programs at all levels to improve services for autistic individuals and their families. SEC. 4. POLICY COMMITTEE; RELATED COMMITTEES. Establishment of a Policy Committee with 17 members, including Presidential appointees and House appointees. Members will have experience in addressing the needs of people with autism spectrum disorders in the United States. The Policy Committee will consist of 17 members, including appointees from the House of Representatives and the Senate. Members will be selected by the Speaker of the House, the minority leader, and the Senate majority. The Policy Committee will consist of 17 members, appointed by leaders from the House of Representatives and the Senate. Selection criteria include consultation with relevant Senate committees and a requirement for 50% of members to come from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia. The Policy Committee will consist of 17 members, appointed by leaders from the House of Representatives and the Senate. Selection criteria include consultation with relevant Senate committees and a requirement for 50% of members to come from private industry, the nonprofit sector, or academia. The committee must include individuals with specific knowledge and experience related to autism, such as parents or legal guardians, experts in intervention programs, education, and housing for individuals with autism. The Policy Committee, consisting of 17 members, will include individuals with expertise in housing for individuals with autism, training for law enforcement on autism response, and environmental factors related to autism development. The committee will make decisions by majority vote. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, requires a quorum to conduct business. Meetings are initially called by the Cochairs within 30 days of the last member selection, with subsequent meetings at the chairperson's discretion. The Committee conducts meetings, hearings, and working sessions to fulfill its duties. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, conducts meetings, hearings, and working sessions to make recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference, propose an agenda, recommend delegates, establish delegate numbers, and create an executive committee. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES.

The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds in the autism and neurodevelopmental disorders field, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and members of the public affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States. In administering this section, the Cochairs shall provide written notice to all members of the Policy Committee of each meeting, request cooperation from other Federal departments, and make a proposed agenda available for public comment. The Cochairs of the Conference on autism are tasked with addressing major issues in the field, providing necessary background materials, and hiring additional personnel as needed, bypassing certain regulations for appointments and pay rates. The Cochairs of the Conference on autism are responsible for ensuring that the proposed agenda is published in the Federal Register, personnel are appointed without bias, and recommendations are implemented. The Conference on autism ensures that recommendations are independent and based on delegates' judgment, supported by current data on autism spectrum disorders in the US for evaluating federal programs and policies. The Cochairs of the Conference on autism spectrum disorders may obtain grants or enter agreements with public agencies or nonprofit organizations to provide resources to delegates. They can also accept gifts on behalf of the United States, including cash or in-kind donations, to support the implementation of the Act. The Cochairs are required to maintain records related to these activities. The Cochairs must keep records of sources, amounts, and uses of gifts accepted, as well as the recipients of assistance and the amount received by each person. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Policy Committee must prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state CEOs. States must submit their views within 45 days. A final report, including chief executives' views, must be prepared within 6 months of adjournment. The Policy Committee must compile and publish the views and findings of state CEOs in a report for administrative action and legislation implementation. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. The Surgeon General must prepare and publish a status report on the implementation of recommendations within 2 years of the Conference adjournment. Subsequent status reports must be submitted every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. The Comptroller General must prepare a status report on the implementation of recommendations and publish it in the Federal Register, and transmit it to the President and Congress once recommendations are achieved. SEC. 9. DEFINITION OF STATE. The term "State" in this Act refers to several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, or the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization is granted to appropriate necessary funds for the first fiscal year of planning the Conference by the Policy Committee, the subsequent fiscal year, and the fiscal year in which the Conference takes place. Any new spending or contract authority that obligates the United States to make payments is limited to specific amounts. Funds appropriated for the Act and gifts received shall be available for 1 year after the Conference adjourns. Unspent funds expire after 1 year. If the Conference is not convened before December 31, 2010, unspent funds shall be returned to the United States Treasury or placed in a trust fund for a future Conference on Autism.
